A subscription service is when game companies ask for a certain sum of money in exchange for your access to their game every week/month/year.

Micro-transactions are in-game items that the user can purchase using real money. The problem with micro-transactions is that the game difficulty is created in such a way that the player can\'t progress in a reasonable amount of time without paying for said micro-transactions. Another issue is that those in-game items are created in such a way that, if you want to keep winning, you will have to keep buying them, ending up spending potentially thousands of real world currency.

A battle pass is a subscription service for micro-transactions. It\'s usually divided into a basic battle pass and a premium battle pass, the premium version offering better rewards. All battle passes are designed in such a way that the player has to keep playing the game in order to get the better and better rewards, making them addicted in the process.

Loot boxes are micro-transactions with a gambling twist. If you thought spending a lot of money on some in-game items is bad, wait until you have to spend this much money and potentially get nothing in return! Yay!

Pay-to-win is a derogatory name for a type of game that implements practices created to make you spend exorbitant amounts of money in order to have a chance at winning the game. Some of those practices were presented above.

Malicious practices are hidden psychological tricks added in games in order to further make you spend more money. Such tricks may include: creating a lot of in-game currencies so that the user is confused when spending them, the main goal being the devaluation of real money.

Concerning terms of service are created in such a way that legally allows the company that owns the game to screw you over, either by stealing all your data, refusing refunds or even monitoring you device.
Fake engagement refers to buying botted positive reviews for a game.

When a game is marked with this tag, it means all the promotional art created in order to advertise that game completely misrepresents the final product. Example: a company releases a trailer that makes their game look like it\'s a third person shooter, but in reality, after you download the game expecting what you saw in the trailer, you find out it\'s just a base building game.
Immoral developers are those who lie to their community and even steal from them.
What is defined as a scam?

A game marked as a scam is a game that was hyped up in order to make people buy or preorder it, but which turned out to be incomplete, buggy and overall a mess at launch, on top of which having developers who ran away with people\'s money, never to return.
